In Fortran, a function can return a long (integer*8). So let's define a function get(a) which returns an integer(8). Now, let's structure the function:

Function Get(a) result(ret)
     integer(8) :: a
     integer(8) :: ret
     integer(8) :: now, t, temp
     now = 1
     t = 1
     ret =0
     do
        if (now * 10 > a) then
           ret = ret + (a - now +1) * t
           exit
        end if
        ret = ret + now *9 *t
        now = now * 10
        t = t +1
     end do
End Function Get

children.text:
Starting with the first function, 'get(a)'. Fortran syntax:

FUNCTION get(a) RESULT(ret)
    INTEGER(8), INTENT(IN) :: a
    INTEGER(8) :: ret, now, t
    now = 1
    t = 1
    ret = 0
    DO
        IF (now * 10 > a) THEN
            ret = ret + (a - now + 1) * t
            EXIT
        END IF
        ret = ret + now *9* t
        now = now * 10
        t = t + 1
    END DO
END FUNCTION get

Wait, but in Fortran, the INTEGER(8) uses 64 bits.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Depending on the compiler, we might need to use integer*8 or selected_int_kind(18).
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
Alternatively, code with the '8' kind parameter. Next the 'binarySearch' function. Let's consider:

FUNCTION binarySearch(k,l,r,x) RESULT(res)
    INTEGER(8), INTENT(IN) :: k, l, r, x
    INTEGER(8) :: res
    IF(r < l) THEN
        res = -1
        RETURN
    END IF
    INTEGER(8) mid = l + (r-l)/2
    mid = ...
    etc.
    Also, the code inside checks mid > ans etc.

children.text: Since 'ans' is also a global variable in the code. But 'ans' is declared as a static long in the Java class, which in Fortran would be a module variable accessible by the function.

children.text:
For Fortran code, all the functions will be in a module, or have access to a common block containing 'ans'. Therefore, in Fortran:

First, define a module to hold the global variable 'ans':

MODULE codeforces_mod
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER(8) :: ans = 0
END MODULE codeforces_mod

Then, the functions can use this 'ans'.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Now, the function 'binarySearch' can be written as recursive, with 'ans' accessible via the module.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Thus, defining the function with:

FUNCTION binarySearch(k,l,r,x) RESULT(res)
    USE codeforces_mod
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER(8), INTENT(IN) :: k, l, r, x
    INTEGER(8) :: res
    INTEGER(8) mid
    IF (r < l) THEN
        res = -1
        RETURN
    END IF
    mid = l + (r - l)/2
    IF (mid > ans .AND. mid*k <= x) THEN
        ans = mid
    END IF
    IF (k*mid ==x) THEN
        res = mid
        RETURN
    ELSE IF (k*mid > x) THEN
        res = binarySearch(k,l,mid-1,x)
    ELSE
        res = binarySearch(k, mid+1, r, x)
    END
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
IF
END FUNCTION binarySearch

RECURSIVE FUNCTION binarySearch(k,l,r,x) RESULT(res)

    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER(8), INTENT(IN) :: k, l, r, x
    INTEGER(8) :: res
    INTEGER(8) :: mid
    ... END FUNCTION But in Fortran, the return variable (res) must be of compatible type. Also, the condition:

if mid *k <=x. So mid is calculated as (l + (r-l)/2), which in integer division. Now, the main program:

This is for the binarySearch function's ans variable usage. END MODULE Then the recursive function for binarySearch:

RECURSIVE FUNCTION binarySearch(k,l,r,x) RESULT(res)
    USE codeforces_mod
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER(8), INTENT(IN) :: k, l, r, x
    INTEGER(8) :: res
    INTEGER(8) :: mid
    IF (r < l) THEN
        res = -1
        RETURN
    END IF
    mid = l + (r - l)/2
    IF (mid > ans .AND. mid * k <= x) THEN
        ans = mid
    END IF
    IF (k * mid ==x) THEN
        res = mid
    ELSE IF (k * mid > x) THEN
        res = binarySearch(k, l, mid-1, x)
    ELSE
        res = binarySearch(k, mid+1, r, x)
    END IF
END FUNCTION binarySearch

Then the get function:

    t =1
    ret =0
    DO
        IF ( now *10 > a ) THEN

Finally, the main program:

PROGRAM codeforces_main
    USE codeforces_mod
    IMPLICIT NONE
    INTEGER(8) :: gen, st, tim, beg, end, med
    ! Read variables:
    READ(*,*) gen, st, tim
    gen = gen / tim
    beg = st -1
    end = 1000000000000000000_8 ! 1e18
    DO
        med = (beg + end)/2 +1
        IF ( get(med) - get(st -1) > gen) THEN
            end = med -1
        ELSE
            beg = med
        ENDIF
        IF ( beg == end ) THEN
            WRITE(*,*) beg - st +1
            STOP
        ENDIF
    END DO
END PROGRAM codeforces_main

children.text:
Include functions here if they are part of the module, but in Fortran we usually have separate functions.
    ! But in this code, the functions are separate

end module codeforces_mod

! recursive binarySearch function:
recursive function binarySearch(k,l,r,x) result(res)
    use codeforces_mod
    implicit none
    integer(8), intent(in) :: k, l, r, x
    integer(8) :: res, mid
    if (r < l) then
        res = -1
        return
    endif
    mid = l + (r-l)/2
    !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
conditions:
    if (mid > ans .and. mid*k <=x) then
        ans = mid
    end if
    if (k*mid ==x ) then
        res = mid
    else if (k*mid >x ) then
        res = binarySearch(k, l, mid-1, x)
    else
        res = binarySearch(k, mid+1,r,x)
    end if
end function binarySearch

! get function
function get(a) result(ret)
    use codeforces_mod
    implicit none
    integer(8), intent(in) :: a
    integer(8) :: ret, now, t
    now = 1
    t = 1
    ret =0
    do
        if (now *10 > a) then
            ret = ret + (a - now +1)*t
            exit
        endif
        ret = ret + now *9 *t
        now = now *10
        t = t+1
    end do
end function get

program codeforces_373_B
    use codeforces_mod
    implicit none
    integer(8) :: gen, st, tim, beg, end, med
    ! Read inputs
    read(*,*) gen, st, tim
    gen = gen / tim
    beg = st -1
    end = 1000000000000000000_8
    do
        med = (beg + end)/2 +1

module codeforces_mod
    implicit none
    integer(8) :: ans = 0
contains

! recursive binarySearch function:
recursive function binarySearch(k,l,r,x) result(res)
    use codeforces_mod
    implicit none
    integer(8), intent(in) :: k, l, r, x
    integer(8) :: res, mid
    if (r < l) then

        return
    endif
    mid = l + (r-l)/2
    ! conditions:
    if (mid > ans .and. mid*k <=x) then
        ans = mid
    end if
    if (k*mid ==x ) then
        res = mid
    else if (k*mid >x ) then
        res = binarySearch(k, l, mid-1, x)
    else
        res = binarySearch(k, mid+1,r,x)
    end if
end function binarySearch

! get function
function get(a) result(ret)
    use codeforces_mod
    implicit none
    integer(8), intent(in) :: a
    integer(8) :: ret, now, t
    now = 1
    t = 1
    ret =0
    do
        if (now *10 > a) then
            ret = ret + (a - now +1)*t
            exit
        endif
        ret = ret + now *9 *t
        now = now *10
        t = t+1
    end do
end function get

program codeforces_373_B
    use codeforces_mod
    implicit none
    integer(8) :: gen, st, tim, beg, end, med
    ! Read inputs
    read(*,*) gen, st, tim
    gen = gen / tim
    beg = st -1
    end = 1000000000000000000_8
    do
        med = (beg + end)/2 +1
        if ( get(med) - get(st-1) > gen ) then
            end = med -1
        else
            beg = med
        end if
        if (beg == end ) then
            write(*,*) beg - st +1
            stop
        end if
    end do
end program codeforces_373_B

Since the user didn't structure them into the module, they can be written as external functions, but they must use the module for the ans variable.

Thus, the structure is okay. The module holds the global 'ans' variable.
